image.altText: China's Qinling base

props.synopsis: When China opened its fifth research station in Antarctica this month, analysts sounded alarm bells about potential security threats on Australia's southern doorstep.

title.children: As China ramps up its presence in Antarctica, analysts say Australia is 'asleep at the wheel'

image.altText: A man and male child sit on a couch reading a book together, you can't see their faces but the child is pointing at the pictures

props.synopsis: While there's no substitute for a qualified teacher, we've asked experts for their best tips for parents who want to help teach their kids to read at home.

title.children: Experts looked at 10,000 pieces of research to find the best way to learn to read – we've distilled it down for you

image.altText: Two men wearing Tshirts with POLICE in yellow writing sit on the back of a boat out on the water

props.synopsis: At its closest point, Papua New Guinea is just 4 kilometres from Australia's islands in the Torres Strait, and local authorities warn this tropical archipelago has become an attractive route for drug smugglers.

title.children: Meth arrives in Australia through many routes, but it's destroying lives on Papua New Guinea's islands near the Torres Strait

image.altText: A Nauru Airlines plane on the tarmac at Broome Airport, viewed through a cyclone fence with a staircase attached,

props.synopsis: Another group of foreign nationals turn up in Western Australia's remote north, following the discovery of around two dozen men near the tiny Indigenous community of Beagle Bay on Friday morning.

title.children: New group of suspected asylum seekers found in WA's north, taking total number to more than 35

image.altText: A composite image of two men with neutral expressions

props.synopsis: Of all Vladimir Putin's critics, Alexei Navalny was probably the most fearless. It's one of the reasons he was so dangerous for the Russian president.

title.children: Courageous, charismatic and funny: Why Navalny was the opposite of Putin

image.altText: A man holds two ventriloquist dummies overlaid on a composite of old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: In 1937, one of the most popular names in American radio stood just 90 centimetres tall and was made of wood and plastic — meet Charlie McCarthy and his puppeteer, Edgar Bergen.

title.children: Famous ventriloquist left his daughter nothing when he died — he bequeathed his puppet a fortune

image.altText: A couple stands at a lookout and smiles

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US, these South Asian women share what being in an interracial relationship has cost them.

title.children: If your parents didn't approve of your partner, would you lie to them so you could live together?

image.altText: The thermodynamic god

props.synopsis: You've heard the arguments to put the brakes on the development of powerful Artificial Intelligence. But this secretive tech movement wants to do exactly the opposite.

title.children: These AI insiders want the controversial technology to be developed faster

image.altText: Hobart CBD buildings seen from a plane window.

props.synopsis: For six years, the Tasmanian Liberals have resisted adding further regulation to Airbnb and Stayz. But as hundreds of properties continue to be taken out of the rental market, they have decided to introduce a levy — to be paid by the visitor, not the owner.

title.children: Liberals promise a levy on Airbnb in Tasmania, saying short stay is impacting rental supply

image.altText: Man in suit wearing thick rimmed glasses holds up fist.

props.synopsis: In 1974, two French doctors were called to the Iranian capital, Tehran. The doctors — specialists in blood diseases — had been asked to assess a government minister with cancer, but the appointment was odd.

title.children: When the Shah of Iran was diagnosed with cancer a revolution was already underway

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: I know exactly your type — you love a weekend quiz and are convinced you'd outperform contestants on my show. Well, prove it.

title.children: Oh, you won a trivia night once? Cute. Now it's time to play, HARD!

image.altText: Australia bowler Annabel Sutherland celebrates a wicket in a Test against South Africa by pointing and shouting.

props.synopsis: More history for Annabel Sutherland, and Australia's spinners finally join the party as South Africa's resistance falls well short. Here are five quick hits from what turned out to be the final day of the standalone Test at the WACA.

title.children: Five quick hits — Perry's praise for heir apparent as Aussies sink stubborn South Africans

image.altText: Potatoes with a graphic of a yellow arrow on the up and +$1bn written on it.

props.synopsis: Australia consistently produces about 1.4 million tonnes of spuds each year and their value is on the rise.

title.children: The humble spud is now a $1 billion industry but a potato farmer says not all growers are benefitting

image.altText: A group of performers on a stage in traditional Palestinian clothing.

props.synopsis: A group of Palestinian performers say organisers of the National Multicultural Festival told them to remove the parts of their play about Gaza for being political. But an ACT government spokeswoman says the original proposed performance had changed to a play from a traditional dance.

title.children: Palestinian performers withdraw from National Multicultural Festival over controversy surrounding Gaza play

image.altText: Albanese addressing reps chamber alongside border force officials at a school with asylum seekers.

props.synopsis: The PM accuses the federal opposition of undermining Australia's border protection regime, arguing its rhetoric is fuelling the illegal people smuggling trade.

title.children: Albanese accuses Dutton of talking down tough border protection regime

image.altText: Three men wearing beanies carry a fourth man by his arms in legs, while walking through the snow.

props.synopsis: More than 100 people are arrested, including a priest who attempted to conduct a service for Alexei Navalny in St Petersburg, while in other cities police took pictures of those who turned out to pay their respects to the late opposition leader.

title.children: Navalny spokesperson alleges he was murdered, demands body be returned to family

image.altText: A besuited man with eyes downcast exits through a sliding glass door

props.synopsis: Sitting MP Ian Goodenough has lost Liberal preselection to former Stirling MP Vince Connelly, marking the second time in a week a Liberal incumbent has failed to become the party's preferred candidate.

title.children: Liberal MP Ian Goodenough warns of 'civil war' after losing Moore preselection, considers independent run

image.altText: Close up of Taylor Swift looking serious on stage in sparkly bodysuit

props.synopsis: There is a hum in the air from the start, a feeling that everyone in the city is tilting their bodies slightly towards the MCG, just waiting for the moment when she will finally take the stage.

title.children: Sparkles, sing-alongs and surprise tracks: Taylor Swift starts the Australian leg of her Eras tour with a bang

image.altText: A body camera shot of a person holding a gun aimed at a tower.

props.synopsis: The timing is critical as Russia is looking for a morale boost ahead of the second anniversary on February 24 of Moscow's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and the March presidential election in Russia.

title.children: Ukraine withdraws beleaguered forces from strategic eastern city Avdiivka

image.altText: person looking out into ocean

props.synopsis: An alleged conversion therapy event divided this country town, but despite promises to outlaw the practice, it's still legal in this state.

title.children: 'They tell you you're worthless, then tell you they can help you': The 'harmful' practice still legal despite promised ban

image.altText: A photo album of images of a boy, and a grown man

props.synopsis: John Steen tried to get his abuser – a priest – away from children. Instead, there was a cover-up, a confidential settlement and misrepresentations. Thirty years later, the church has been ordered to pay him $2.4 million.

title.children: John wanted justice. Instead, bishops hid files in a garage. Now the church must pay him $2.4 million

image.altText: An H3 rocket lifts off at Tanegashima Space Center in Kagoshima, southern Japan.

props.synopsis: The launch further enhances the country's space credentials, following the historic "pinpoint" moon landing of Japan's SLIM spacecraft last month.

title.children: After initial failure, Japan successfully launches new H3 space rocket

image.altText: A satellite image of flattened ground

props.synopsis: Egypt is warning Israel not to forcibly expel the more than one million displaced Palestinians now in Rafah into its territory.

title.children: Egypt building wall along Gaza border, satellite images suggest

image.altText: Twisted metal transmission towers under a grey sky.

props.synopsis: AusNet says power was restored to another 7,000 homes affected by Tuesday's electricity outage, but 15,000 properties in the Gippsland area remain cut off and some may not be back on the network for several days.

title.children: Power restored to more Victorian homes but thousands remain without electricity

image.altText: People gather at a temple fair amid Lunar New Year celebrations in Beijing, China February 11, 2024.

props.synopsis: For some young Asians, Lunar New Year isn't as rosy and celebratory as many people believe. It's also a time when they are grilled by parents, grandparents, uncles and aunties about why they're not married yet, or if they are married, why they don't have children yet.

title.children: These are the uncomfortable questions that many young Asians brace themselves for during Lunar New Year

image.altText: Ex-Lincoln 840am Sat

props.synopsis: Heavy rainfall and strong winds are forecast across parts of the Northern Territory as ex-Tropical Cyclone Lincoln tracks further inland, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

title.children: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Lincoln moves west over northern Australia, as heavy rainfall continues

image.altText: Jordan Spieth holds a club in his right hand during a 2024 US PGA Tour event.

props.synopsis: Jordan Spieth, a three-time major winner, commits an embarrassing career-first mistake after 263 starts on the US PGA Tour, while Jason Day is in contention at the Riviera Country Club in California.

title.children: Former world number one Spieth disqualified from US tournament after rookie error

image.altText: Liam Moffitt dressed in bright red helmet, custom-made firefighting uniform, holding trauma teddy

props.synopsis: Liam Moffitt wants to visit as many of the 334 Fire and Rescue stations in New South Wales as he can as part of a fundraising mission for burns survivors.

title.children: 4yo aspiring firefighter 'walks into station like he owns it' on 85th station visit

image.altText: Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex visits the Whistler Sliding Centre in Canada.

props.synopsis: King Charles's cancer diagnosis could bring the British royal family closer, Prince Harry says, adding that he loved his family and was grateful to have recently seen his father.

title.children: 'I love my family': Prince Harry says he is hopeful King Charles's cancer could bring royal family closer

image.altText: A brown snake caught in a web by a redback spider

props.synopsis: They may be one of Australia's most deadly animals but Peter Marchal says it is not the first time he has seen a redback spider triumph against an eastern brown snake.

title.children: Redback spider catches baby eastern brown snake in its web
